scenes.location: CASCADE MOUNTAIN RANGE. WASHINGTON STATE. DAWN. 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the early morning dawn, the Skykomish River in Washing State's Cascade Mountain Range pounds against the granite river rocks. Giant Fir branches in the lush forest undulate, almost dancing in the soft wind. A BLACK-TAILED BUCK makes its way through the dense woods The deer walks to the bank, dips its mouth into the river and drinks. Tall grass parts and out of the morning fog comes a young man, completely COVERED IN MUD, a massive, serrated hunti knife in his hands. This is BODEVAN. He's 18, with wispy hair down to his shoulders. The deer turns its head, sensing something. Bo freezes - perfectly camouflaged in the tall grass. The deer sniffs the air, but as Bo is covered in mud and animal skins, it smells nothing. It relaxes, drinking fro the river again. Bo exhales, silently. In a flash, Bo leaps out of the grass and in one continuo motion, tackles the deer and slices the animal’s carotid artery. The deer does nothing more than flinch, blood spu from it’s neck and it just folds, hemorrhagic shock takin over. It's a perfect kill. Bo watches and the animal takes its final breath. Then he signals and five KIDS glide into the clearing. Th range in age from 14 to 6, all have long, unruly hair, di faces, and wear, over the usual kid's clothes of t-shirts jeans, what looks like animal skins. They are: two twin 1 year old girls, KIELYR and VESPYR; RELLIAN, a boy of 13; ZAJA, a 8-year old girl; and lastly, NAI, a 6-year old bo The other kids surround Bo, staring down at the fallen de (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Like some primordial warrior, his upper body camouflaged mud, BEN CASH rises out of the grass. He's 45 and has a formidable beard, but his body is lithe and muscular, fit like a man half his age. Ben plunges his finger in the deer's throat. He paints a stripe of blood across Bo's face.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Today. The boy is dead. And in his place. Is a man. Everyone pauses for the deep solemnity of the moment. Bo slits open the animal; its innards spill onto the eart Ben raises his hands high in the air and - as if he's say a prayer - closes his eyes. The IMAGE FREEZES - as the title comes up around him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trailed by the rest of the family, Ben and Bo carry the d legs tied to a tree limb - through the thick forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Ben and Bo attach the deer's feet to rope, swing th rope over a tree, and string it high off the ground, we g our first glimpse of their "home." In a clearing, hidden under a canopy of enormous Douglas trees, next to a small greenhouse garden - a large Tipi s behind a fire pit. A few of the kids jump on small wooden platforms, grab hanging rope, and pull themselves up on these little "elevators." Cascading high into the trees above the Tipi a kid's paradise of funky tree houses, zip lines, rope bridges, hammocks, and observation platforms. Rellian strums on a guitar. He sings "Little Red Corvette Prince. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Training in one hour! Ben watches as, in front of their Tipi, strung from a rop on a tree, the twins skin the deer that Bo shot: peeling its hide with none of the squeamishness of 15-year olds a all the skill of experienced butchers. Behind them, 12-year old Rellian, with a flint that he extracts from a pouch on his belt, makes a fire in a larg pit in front of the Tipi.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: Dad. Where's the boning knife? Zaja. Ben nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben climbs up a wood ladder, ducking intricately woven branches to enter what looks like a massive bird's nest. Zaja sits on the floor, cleaning the skeleton of a small animal with a 6-inch boning knife. Inside, the tree house has been turned into some kind of grotesque Death Shrine. It's plastered with actual animal skeletons, magazine photographs of dead bodies from the Holocaust, and pictures of Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge. F the look on Ben's face, this is the first time he's seen Zaja's interior design.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jesus. Zaja looks at the photo on the wall. She shakes her head

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Pol Pot. Ben puts out his hand and Zaja passes him the boning knif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a mountain meadow, Ben and the kids, their eyes closed sit cross-legged in a circle. Silence. Apart from the rustle of the leaves as the wind blows thr the trees, the occasional chirping of distant birds. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ben opens his eyes and says, "Okay." All the children jump up, wooden sticks in their hands, a Ben teaches them what looks like commando knife-fighting. This is not a suburban mall karate class. Bo slashes at Ben with his stick. In one swift movement, deflects with his forearm and hip-throws Bo. Bo hits the ground hard, Ben's stick already pressing into Bo's throa kill strike, shocking in its sudden violence. The others watch, taking all of this utterly seriously, t break into pairs and practice the move. Rellian glares at his father, but makes no move to join. Ben watches Kielyr and Vespyr. They're attacking and defending like it's a choreographed dance.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: If you don't stab to kill. Really stab. For the liver. Or the kidneys. She'll never learn.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we aim here? A knife in the lungs creates pneumothorax. Or next to the sternum, to penetrate the heart? That would be instant death. Ben looks over at his 8-year old, standing next to Nai.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: If it makes you happy, Zaj. Sure. Aim for the heart. Vespyr eyes her sister, but is still hesitating.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The stick will break before it hurts her. Vespyr attacks again, but this time she overcompensates, Kielyr's parry is ineffectual, and Vespyr's stick hits he sister in the stomach. The stick breaks and Kielyr YELPS pain.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: What?! How is that good? She stabbed me! She fucking stabbed me!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Then you better learn to defend yourself. Ben hands Vespyr another stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flames illuminate the faces of the family, as they eat ro venison, sitting on the ground in a circle around the fir By the light of candles and kerosene lamps, the kids are reading books way beyond their years: Nai is reading the Encyclopedia Brittanica, he's on letter "J"; Kielyr is reading "Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies" by Jared Diamond; Rellian reads Dostoyevsky's Brothers Karamazov;" Bo is reading a college Calculus textbook.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Zaj. Page. Zaja holds "Middlemarch" by George Eliot. She glances at page number.
Ben records this in a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You still liking it? Zaja nods.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you would. To stay on schedule for the test you need to be finished in 8 days. Vesp? Vespyr holds "The Fabric of the Cosmos: Space, Time, and Texture of Reality" by Brian Greene.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: Just finished Chapter 12, "The World on a String." Ben looks up at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Are you having trouble with quantum entanglement?

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Planck length vs. Planck time?

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Good, then tomorrow you can give a little presentation on M-Theory, argue counter-points with Bo and Rell vis-a-vis Witten and Dirac. Vespyr makes a face at Kielyr. Neither sees that Ben catc the look. Ben puts down his notebook. He watches the children readi for a moment. Then he picks up his guitar. Improvises a rhythmic strum. Punctuates it with little, abrupt vocalizations. So funky can't help but be drawn in. The kids ignore him, but gradually, one at a time, each o them pick up a different musical instrument - a flute, dr a trombone, a violin - and joins him. Soon, everyone is up on their feet. Dancing and singing a playing their instruments - illuminated by the light of t fire - grooving to their improvised song and having a bla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaping over stumps, ducking under branches, Ben and the race through the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From out of his workshop shed, Ben carries some handmade wooden birdhouses, helped by Bo and Vespyr.  GREEN (9.2.2014) 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and the kids walk toward a a beat-up, 36-foot long bl 1989 Thomas Saf-T-Liner school bus, parked on a forest pa

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Try not to kill each other before we get back.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: If training is over today, can we take Steve somewhere for class time later?

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: Why don't we have a Mommy? This catches the attention of all the kids. They all stop look at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You do have a Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: You said she would only be gone for a week.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It hasn't been very long.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: It's been three months, two weeks, six days, and eleven hours.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Mom is very ill.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: Don't talk to us like we're your inferiors.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Who knew there were so many geniuses in the world.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: Dad, Bo is being sarcastic.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That was sardonic. Sarcastic would be... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GREEN, (9.2.2014)
dialogues.text: As

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Your genius is blinding." They're both mocking, but sarcastic is directed at a person and meant to hurt. Sardonic is less direct and is said more for laughs or for wit. Grab the end.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: We DO know about Mom.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: You think you do, but you have no concept of the scope or the depth of her illness.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: Dad, Bo is being condescending.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Bo's right. Mom has to be ina hospital now.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: But you said hospitals are only a great place to go to if you're a healthy person and you want to die.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: You said Americans are undereducated and overmedicated.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: You said that the AMA are avaricious whores only too willing to spread their fat legs for Big Pharma.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Not enough of the neurotransmitter serotonin to conduct electrical signals in Mom's brain. A lack of receptor sites. Acute tryptophan depletion. We don't know exactly what it is. Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors - Celexa, Lexapro, Paxil, Zoloft - or Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors - Cymbalta, Effexor, Pristiq - it's simply the most effective way to manage it.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: Exactly when is Mom coming back? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 GREEN (9.2.2014) 9. CONTINUED: As

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That's what I'm going to find out. Ben, Bo, Vespyr, and Kielyr climb on the bus and we see t the interior has been customized, the rows of seats remov and replaced with a full library, a closet full of clothe desks, maps on the walls, loft beds in the back. Ben clos the doors and, on the outside of the glass door panels is spray-painted, stenciled word: “Steve.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve the Bus winds down through the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bo, Vespyr, and Kielyr sit in a dentist’s waiting room, mMarvelling at the synthetic, brightly-colored office. Pe MUZAK plays as Ben approaches the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We have an appointment. Vespyr and Kielyr Cash. My daughters. They’re 15. It’s time they see a dentist. The RECEPTIONIST stares at him. She checks the appointmen book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bo and Ben are unloading their handmade wooden birdhouses front of a store. A group of TEENAGE GIRLS walk out and o of them smiles at Bo.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL
dialogues.text: You comin' in? Bo shrugs, avoiding her eyes. TEENAGE GIRL (CONT’D) Yes? No? Okay. 'Bye. Bo turns red and just nods. As the girls walk away, the one who held the door for Bo looks back at him, then says something to her friends, wh all check Bo out and giggle.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Go talk to her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Ask her what she thinks about the working people creating an armed revolution against the exploiting classes and their state structures?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Marxists can be just as genocidal as.... No. Just... I don't know. Talk about -

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Whether or not she's a Dialectical Materialist and accords primacy to the class struggle?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Avoid... Marxism. Or telling her you're a Trotskyite.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: "Trotskyist." Only a Stalinist would call a Trotskyist a "Trotskyite." And I'm not a Trotskyist anymore. I'ma Maoist. Ben nods. He hands Bo a key and Bo walks away. The STORE OWNER comes out and hands Ben a wad of cash.

dialogues.speaker: STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: Sold all the stuff from last time. You said you’d be back months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bo opens a large post office box. Inside, the box is pack with mail. There are the new issues of "Scientific Americ "National Geographic," "The New Yorker," and "The Economi And then a stack of large envelopes. Bo looks at the first one. It's marked, "PRINCETON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In another corner of the post office, Bo holds up a piece paper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It reads, "We are pleased to welcome you to Harvard University, the class of 2015." He looks at the other envelopes, all now opened, spread o the counter before him. They are from Dartmouth, Brown, M.I.T., Yale, and Stanford. On top of the opened envelopes are welcome letters from e university.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the front of the bar, Ben dials a number on the house phone. We don't see who he's talking to (but will come to realize that it's HARPER, his sister).

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ben? Immediately, from the tone of Harper's voice, Ben can tel something is very wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What is it? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harper. Ben hears a sharp, irregular exhalation of breath. Whatev is wrong is serious enough to be very difficult to say.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Leslie killed herself last night. The blood drains from Ben's face. He is frozen for a mome No reaction whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: How? Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harper, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She jumped out of a window. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now Ben swallows. But nothing else. No emotion whatsoever nods.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ben? Ben hangs up the phone. INT. STEVE - MOVING. DAY. Al4 Ben drives in silence. He looks in the rearview mirror, a Bo, Vespyr, and Kielyr. They stare out the window, comple unaware of his recent phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Illuminated by candles and kerosine lamps, all the kids s together, dressed for bed, staring expectantly at their father. Ben takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Last night. Mommy killed herself. She jumped out of a window. Your mother is dead. As the reality of Ben's words hit them, utter devastation passes over the children's face. And then, in a matter of seconds, they all burst into tears, snot comes out of the noses, tears roll down their faces, some of them are almo hyperventilating. Grieving openly and deeply, it's like something out of Greek Tragedy. Elemental. Primal.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: What's going to happen to us?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Nothing is going to change. We'll continue living exactly the same way. We're a family. Rellian stands. He yells. Savage, guttural shouts. They'r fierce and pained, like a trapped animal.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: Mom! Mom! He picks up a knife, but just paces, red-faced, not knowi what to do with it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bodevan moves to stop his brother, but Ben holds Bo's shoulder. Rellian takes the knife and stabs, over and over again, i the side of a cabinet. Harder and harder. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you! Fuck you! Mom! Mom! Fuck you, Mom, you fucking...! Rellian drops the knife and runs out of the Tipi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESLIE's face. Smiling. Giggling. She is leaning over, swaying back and forth, dragging her long auburn hair across Ben's face. She dips down and kisses him. Over and over again. She's laughing. She SPEAKS, but NO SOUND comes out of her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben opens his eyes. He sits up and blinks, peering into t darkness of the Tipi. The kids are asleep. Leslie is not there. He lights a candle and opens a dresser. Under his clothes withdraws a hidden manila folder. One file is marked WILL TESTAMENT. He rifles through the papers until he finds wh he's looking for. He reads. His face turns white.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jesus fucking Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben stands outside the Tipi. He brings his bagpipes to hi lips and blows. Out comes that eerie and persistent WAIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben bolts through a dense rainforest - creating an obstac course as he goes - dodging trees, bounding over rocks an fallen logs. Straggling behind, the kids all follow his exact movement (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He reaches a meadow, stops, and clicks his stopwatch as e kid passes him. First comes Bo.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: 1:05. Worse than yesterday! Then the twins.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 1:11. I'm embarrassed for you. Then Rell.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 1:18. You're plateauing. You're going back to eccentric contractions and leg cycling. Then Zaja and Nai pass him.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 1:26 and... 1:29. Fine if you both were THREE! Subpar! This is subpar! No rest! Ben dodges back the woods and the kids follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a meadow, Ben leads everyone through a complicated ser of calisthenics: jump squats into burpies into holding pl This is hard-core functional training and the kids move through the exercises like athletes.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: The Rule of Three. Nai.

dialogues.speaker: NAI
dialogues.text: You can survive 3 minutes without air.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Zaj.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: You can survive 3 hours without shelter. The kids are in plank, holding themselves in a push-up position only by their elbows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Kielyr.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: 3 days without water.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Vesp.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: 3 weeks without food.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hold it.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Keep holding. Rell. The kids are now really struggling, sweating, their small bodies quivering with effort.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: 3 years without human companionship.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: DAD! When's Mom's funeral?! Ben finally turns to look at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is again on the bar’s house phone, now talking to Leslie's father, JACK.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The utter recklessness, the instability and insecurity that you have brought to her life -

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: WE decided to live here. BOTH of us. This was a mutual decision.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is YOUR goddamned fault! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Leslie had a disease. She needed to be in a good facility, you'll only pay if she's treated near you, fine. We did that. Listen. I found her Will. I assume you know that Leslie was a Buddhist. There is a long pause on the line.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Leslie was a nudist?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Buddhist. Leslie was a BUDDHIST. She wanted to be cremated. Not buried. It was very important to her that -

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I have just lost my only child. I’m in no mood to discuss the particulars of her funeral.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: There's more. Look, this is... strange, I admit, but in her Will, Leslie clearly stipulated that -

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I rue the day she met you. Wherever you are, you stay there.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I miss grandchildren. But you are not welcome here. Is that clear? You show up. I will have you arrested. The phone goes silent.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Can we just speak civilly? Hello? ABIGAIL, Leslie's mother, now speaks.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Leslie is in Heaven now. She is finally at peace.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: When's the ceremony? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In five days. Here in Albuquerque. At our church. How're the children?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They're... in shock.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's been years.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Did you hear what Jack just said?

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I miss them. The children.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jack just said he'll have us arrested if we come. Did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He's very upset. I'm sorry. It's best to do what he says. There's a CLICK and a DIAL TONE as she hangs up the phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Ben cooks venison over a large fire, the kids, all in their private thoughts, stare into the flames. Nai exits the Tipi. He's completely naked.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Mom hated that world.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Clothes when we eat. Nai disappears back into the Tipi.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: We're in the very unique position of hating those people.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Can "unique" be modified? All the other kids respond with a "no." Nai comes out of the Tipi wearing a beat-up Whale costume (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: We don't hate Nana and Grandpa, but the rest of her tribe are fascist capitalists.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: You're just repeating whatever Dad says.

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: I'm writing down everything you say. In my mind.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: You don't even know what a fascist is.

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: Violent nationalist militants, supported by big business and they're totalitarian single-party dictators. Kielyr pauses for a second, surprised by the accuracy of Nai's description.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: We're her family. We have to go.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR
dialogues.text: Grandpa said we can't. Ben takes venison off the fire and cuts it into small pie KIELYR (CONT’D) What will happen if they arrest you? Will they take us away from you? At this, all the kids turn to look at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: There is that possibility. Zaja comes out from the greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Dad. I think Rellian ran away again. EXT. FOREST. EVENING. Ben walks silently through the forest. 23 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He finds Rellian sitting on a rock by an old tree. Rellia doesn't turn to look at his father.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: How'd you find me so quickly? Ben points to the earth, Rellian's shoe prints in the dir

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You don't want to be followed, you should take off your shoes. Rell is silent.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom's illness had nothing to do with you guys. It was chemical. She loved you very much. None of this is your fault. But I can't help you. Unless you talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: All we do is fucking talk! Why won’t you let us see Mom?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Come here, buddy. Rellian bolts up and dodges Ben.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: I hate my fucking shit-ass life! Rell storms back in the direction of the Tipi and Ben follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben awakes and climbs down the ladder to the floor of the Tipi. The children are gone, their beds empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben opens the Tipi to see his kids, like they're on a tra platform waiting to depart, all standing out in front of Tipi; they've got old suitcases and duffel bags, packed a ready. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: We want to see Mom. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: I want to give a speech. Tell Mommy that I love her. For the last time ever.

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR

dialogues.text: But Noam was born on Dec. 7th.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Well. We're celebrating it today. Ben cuts the cake and as soon as he passes them a piece, kids practically inhale it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the floorboards, Ben flips open a trapdoor - reveali large storage area. He grabs a poster board of Noam Choms and a pile of wrapped presents.  52 GREEN (9.2.2014) 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone, apart from Rellian, sings the family's version the "Happy Birthday Song." "Noam! Uncle Noam! Today! The of your birth, all hail!" as Bo and Ben hand out presents The kids rip at the wrapping paper. Bo pulls out an exqui recurve hunting bow with inlays of various woods.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It's a 55-pound pull. Laminated wood and glass. Silent and fast. As Bo tests the pull, the twin girls and Zaja unwrap mass knives, as long as their forearms.

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR VESPYR
dialogues.text: A new knife! So beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: KA-BAR fighting knife! Thanks, dad!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: 7 inch blade, partially serrated. Handle’s slip resistant. Good balance if you dip down when you cut. Nai's present is an old, 1970s copy of "The Joy of Sex." flips through it, eyes wide.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pictures. Nai stares at a drawing. He looks horrified. Rellian opens his present: it's a new recurve like Bo's a quiver of arrows. But he just puts them on the table and sits, staring at his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Those are Black Storm Broadheads. Razor sharp.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: What kind of crazy person celebrates Noam Chomsky's BIRTHDAY like it's some kind of official holiday?! Why can't we just celebrate Christmas like the entire world?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You would prefer to celebrate a magical fictitious elf instead of a living humanitarian who has done so much to further human rights and understanding? Rell just stares at his dad.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's have a discourse.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No. Explain. Take the opportunity provided to make your case. We are all open to hearing your arguments. If they're valid, if you persuade us, I'm absolutely open to changing.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: No, it's great. Yea, Noam Chomsky Day! Rell stomps toward the bus. Nai opens another present. It's the same knife Ben gave t the twins. Now Nai's face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: Yes! Thanks, dad. Little Nai runs up and hugs his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now back on the road, Bo stands and approaches Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: I want to go to college. Ben laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're not all going to just live with you forever. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This stops Ben. He stares at his son.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I have to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVEN
dialogues.text: There's nothing to think about.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You're too young.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: You said my training was done.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: So let me go. Ben stares at Bo for a moment. He shakes his head no. Bo slams his fist into a seat and stomps back to his slee loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Steve travels along, the rural communities of Northern California slowly transform into suburbia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve now drives through the outskirts of Sacramento, California, and into rush hour. Ben picks up the PA radio

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Today's Great Human Being is a man named Enrique Pefalosa, the Major of Bogataé, Columbia from 1998 to 2001. Pefialosa completely re-envisioned the idea of "city;" beautiful, functional public space designed to promote daily human interaction among people of all incomes and races. He massively restricted cars, created vast acres of bikes lanes and green spaces, emphasizing the happiness and safety of children. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What we have HERE is an example of Calvin Coolidge's “The business of America is business.” ExxonMobil, Chevron and ConocoPhillips collectively made $58.3 BILLION last year. Instead of spending our money on health care, education, infrastructure, we shall pray at the altar of Saudi Princes, we enter - for oil - unwinnable foreign wars, spend your tax dollars on the occupation of foreign countries, create more enemies who want to kill us. Good American men and women die every day. Our democracy is one of the brightest lights of social justice in the history of humankind. But hear freedom ring! Let's go shopping! We can drive to the Mall!

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: What about Prince?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Different one. The kids stare out the window, amazed at the endless mile cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve winds through tree-lined, middle-class neighborhood Most of the homes are new and have grass lawns out front. The bus stops in front of a two-story house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUSTIN, Harper's 15-year old son, sits in front of his computer. He wears over-sized skater clothes and has a sh head. He shows Rellian how to play Grand Theft Auto 5. Rellian is in heaven. Over the SOUNDS of EXPLOSIONS and GUNFIRE and SCREAMS, Bo Kielyr, Vespyr, and Zaja just sit on Jackson's bed, tryin make sense of this alien environment. The walls are plastered with band and movie posters. Peop they don't recognize and movies they've never seen or hea of.  59 GREEN (9.2.2014) 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nai is alone in the living room, staring at a framed photograph on the wall. The photograph is of Ben and Leslie, taken at their weddi She wears a white dress and pushes cake into Ben's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Life's a bitch. Nai turns to see JACKSON, Harper's 13-year old son. He is dressed in the same over-sized skater clothes as his brot and has the same shaved head.

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Then you die. Nai nods. JACKSON (CONT’D) Life fucking sucks, man. Nai has no answer for this. He bites his lip.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dinner! Everyone!

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Dude. Jackson just nods his head over and over. Then he spots t knife on Nai's belt. JACKSON (CONT’D) Whoa! Can I check that out? Nai hands Jackson his new knife. Jackson swings it around JACKSON (CONT’D) Rad. Harper comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Boys, dinner! Her face drains of blood when she sees the knife. She rus over and yanks the knife away from Jackson. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ben! Ben!! Ben runs in.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What? What?! Harper holds out the knife.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jesus, you scared me. It's okay. It's Nai's.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: This is Nai's? Nai is 6.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Do I really have to say this out loud? Why does a 6-year old have a real sword?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It's not a sword. It's a knife.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Why does a 6-year old have a knife... this BIG?!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It's primarily for butchering meat, but you can use it for making skins, creating shelters. It has many uses. Harper stares at her brother for a minute. Then she shake her head, resigned disappointment on her face.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: I'm putting this in the knife drawer. He can have it back when you leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining room is nothing especially elegant, but compar to what Ben's kids are used to, this is very formal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Napkins are lined up at every seat and glasses and silver set out. Harper and Dave are placing food on the table: roasted chicken, mashed potatoes, and salad.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Jackson! Now! Jackson sulks in. His face is buried in his Nintendo DS.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not at the table. Jackson plops down and continues to play.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Alright! Once everyone sits, they pass the food around and Dave ho up the wine bottle for Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Everything is local and organic and non-GMO. I'm just saying. Ben smiles and Dave passes Ben the wine bottle. Ben pours himself a glass.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Bo, little Syrah? Bodevan nods and Ben pours his 18-year old son some wine. Justin and Jackson freeze, wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It's one of the great pleasures in life, it's not crack.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: What's crack? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: A crystallized, highly addictive form of the stimulant cocaine. Accelerated the decimation of urban inner-city neighborhoods in the mid- 1980s. Crack-heads, some of them just kids, were killing each other for their Nikes. Harper smiles. Weakly.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Children do not drink wine.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: In France, children drink wine all the time. It's a digestive.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Well, we're not in France. Ben smiles. He puts the wine glass down.

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: They killed each other for Nike? The Greek winged Goddess of Victory? At this, Justin and Jackson laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: He's joking, right? They can see, by their cousin's faces, that he is not.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: They're like Adidas. But cooler.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Who's Adidas? Justin and Jackson cannot believe their ears.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: You're serious? Zaja nods.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: They're shoes. Everyone is silent for a moment. Harper and Dave share a look. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Ben. We're... I'm so sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I don't... really know what else to say. Dave looks at Harper for help.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It's okay. I know you had issues with Leslie. It's not a secret.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say that!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Last time we saw you, you called her a "fucking bitch."

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Ben!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It's okay. The kids know. Right guys? All of his kids nod, completely unaffected by it. Justin and Jackson look absolutely stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No, wait. I said... we all had a huge fight about sugar... I gave the kids Frosted Mini-Wheats! The extremity of her position... She was YELLING at me, she PUSHED me, and I said -

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: "Don't be such a fucking bitch."

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Ben!

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: That kind of language is inappropriate in front - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They're just words. YOUR words. But just words.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Not spoken in this household.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Understood. There is another protracted and awkward silence. Dave loo very concerned.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My point was... it's not easy to express... to try and articulate... When someone dies.... Dave gives up. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're all... devastated. We’re just... so sorry. Ben nods.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: None of us grew up with a ritual that helps us deal with the confusion and sorrow that comes with death.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Dad, how did Aunt Leslie die? Dave looks at Ben. Then back at his son.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Well. Aunt Leslie was sick. And she had some... complications. From her sickness.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: She had a mental illness called Bipolar Affective Disorder. We think it first started after Bo was born, the genesis of which was probably a form of postpartum psychosis. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her moods would swing radically from "mania," she would be elated, have so many plans and ideas for the future, to severe depression, where she'd be almost catatonic, utterly without hope. We weren't really able to diagnose the -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: I'm not sure the kids need to know all the details. Dave tries to take over.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: The doctors put her in the hospital. They gave her medicine. But she was... really sick. And she... died. Sick people die. Sometimes. They die. And she... she just... died. Died of... Because she was sick. She died. His children look at him, confused by the inadequacy of h explanation. DAVE (CONT’D) These things can be very difficult to explain.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: She jumped out a window. She killed herself.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Ben!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: My kids know. Harper bursts into tears and runs from the room. Dave pau Then he stands.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Dave follows Harper. As soon as he's gone, Ben pours wine into each of his kid glasses. Then he holds up his wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: To Mom. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: All the kids say "to Mom," clink their glasses, and drink Ben looks at Justin and Jackson, holding a finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the back lawn behind Harper's house, Ben drops some du bags; he checks and re-checks supplies.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: We do the best we can! That's all everyone's doing. The best they know how! I'm sorry it does not meet your high standards!

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: This is a very hard time right now, we're all still probably in shock. Everyone's very... raw.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I was simply telling them the truth.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Protecting children from certain concepts that they're too young to comprehend is not lying to them!

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Guys. Let's keep our voices down here. Ben looks at his sister.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I apologize. I'm sorry for not respecting the way you do things in your home.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you for saying that. Harper wipes the tears from her eyes. Her tension decreas her voice now tender and sympathetic. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know Leslie's been sick for years. But I can only imagine how difficult this time must be for you. Ben's kids come out of the house; they find and climbs in their sleeping bags.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No, hey. What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We're sleeping under the stars.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: We made up the rec room downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Who wants to sleep on Toy Story sheets? None of the kids have any idea what Harper and Dave are talking about, but the idea of sleeping inside is obvious attractive.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Can we?

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: Can we, Dad? Ben ignores the hopeful faces of his kids.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We're fine here. Harper and Dave look at the kids. They are plainly not fi with this decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the morning chaos in every house with kids and paren who work. Harper simultaneously clears the breakfast dish and, at the same time, is packing up lunch for Justin and Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: We're going to fly in Sunday morning. We can only stay until after the ceremony because the kids have school on Monday. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jackson is playing his Nintendo DS under the table.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Can I be excused?

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: "May I..." No, you may not. Put that away or I'm going to break it in half and throw it in the trash can.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Alright!

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Actually, you may be excused on one condition. Please show your cousins your new hamster.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Can we play Xbox after? Harper looks at Dave.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: One game.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN JACKSON
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! All the kids jump up and follow Justin and Jackson into t adjacent room. VIDEO GAME SOUNDS start almost immediately Dave and Harper exchange a look. Dave nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They're fine. They're strong. Ben clears the table and starts washing the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How long have you been there? Wherever it is you're living now.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We left Boulder when Bo was about 3. Lived on that farm we had in Oregon until he was 7. No, 8. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess we've only been in the forest for... about 10 years.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How do you still have money? Ben smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I buy only what I need.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: But how do you -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: You want to live in the trees, fine, that's entirely up to you. But your children are without a mother now. What you do will have a lasting impact on their entire lives.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And that. That is precisely WHY I am doing what I am doing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: We're really - may I? Harper nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harper and I have been talking... The kids need stability. Structure. Like normal kids. They need to go to a real school. So they can get real jobs when they're -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Oh, for Christ's sake. Harper just can't take it anymore. She jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to get them killed! You have any idea what you're doing to them?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Saving their lives is what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be ridiculous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Is knowing how to set a bone or treat a severe burn ridiculous? Is knowing how to navigate by the stars in total darkness ridiculous? How to identify edible plants, how to make clothes from animal skins, how to survive in the forest with nothing but a knife? Harper looks ashen.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They have the cardiovascular and muscular endurance levels of elite athletes.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: They're children! They need to go to school and learn about the world!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jackson! Justin! Come here a second. After a moment, Jackson and Justin peek in.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: How old are you now, Jackson?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Can you tell me, what's the Bill of Rights? Jackson shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: What something costs?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Justin, you're 15, right? What is that, ninth grade?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That's High School now? You like your school? Justin shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you tell me what the Bill of Rights is?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: A government thing. Like rights that people have and stuff. In America.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Could you be more specific? Justin shrugs again.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Zaja! Come here please! Ben turns to Harper and Dave.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Zaja just turned 8, by the way. Zaja walks in.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Bill of Rights.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: The first ten amendments to the constitution, limiting the power of the government and guaranteeing our liberties and freedoms.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: More specific.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Amendment 1: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Stop. Regurgitating memorized amendments is not what I'm asking. I think we went over this pretty well. Zaja bites her lip.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Without the Bill of Rights, we'd be more like... China. For instance. Here at least warrantless searches are illegal; we have free speech; citizens are protected from cruel and unusual punishment, are protected from -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: How would you characterize the 2010 Supreme Court decision on Citizens United?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Ben.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Corporations have the same rights as people, so there's no spending limit on candidates. Which means our country is ruled by Corporations and their lobbyists who fund candidates and command their fealty by demanding that -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Enough! Okay? Jesus Christ, Ben! You made your point! We get it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Wouldn't that be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve pulls away, leaving Harper, Dave, Jackson, and Just watching from the curb. Nai looks out the back window of the bus and waves. Behind their parent's backs, Jackson and Justin surreptitiously flip off Nai.  64 65 66 67 GREEN (9.2.2014) 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve travels down Highway 99, through the Central Valley

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun sets, the bus makes its way through the suburb Flagstaff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve pulls into a RV park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is now parked alongside rows of Winnebagos. Ben and are out front, fixing dinner. A small RV pulls up along side Steve. CLAIRE, a pretty teenager, comes out.

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: I'm going for wood. Ben looks over to see Nai holding a small axe.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Come here. Ben bends down into the pre-made fire pit, lights a match turns a switch and - instant fire.

dialogues.speaker: NAI
dialogues.text: That's cheating.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. Claire and Bo make eye contact, but Bo looks away. ELLEN, Claire's Mom, exits her RV. She's about Ben's age attractive.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Hello. Ben smiles and nods. Ellen watches Ben for a minute, as he sets up dinner for kids. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know anything about broken heaters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Removed from the main RV area, on a lawn by a playground, Bodevan is moving through a series of yoga Vinyasa.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is that yoga? Bodevan looks over to see Claire sitting on her skateboar smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Your breath, they call it "pranayama," flows with your movements, your "asana." It's supposed to connect the mind and body and fuel your "samadhi."

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That really works? Bo shrugs. Claire moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Really? You in college? Bo pauses again, then nods his head yes.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where do you go?

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Seriously? Bo nods again.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love Boston. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's... pretty cool. I mean, the Boston Massacre. The Boston Tea Party. Battle of Bunker Hill. The Siege of Boston. It has a rich history for an American city. Plus, you know, it's the home of America's first public school. Boston Latin in 1635. First subway in the U.S. In 1897. It also - Claire laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That was tweaky. That was like Wikipedia. I'm Claire.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Bodevan.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Bodevan? What kind of name is that?

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: My parents made it up.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That's weird. Why?

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Our names are unique. There's just one of us in the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That's weird. Bo nods. He looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ben tries to diagnose the problem, Ellen trails him ar her RV. He lights all the burners on her stove. They all work.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'd have the system checked to make sure there's no LP leaks. If that's clear, have the LP pressure set, so you'll know if you have a faulty regulator. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If that's okay and you can set the pressure at 11 inches of water column, then you have to figure out how air is getting in. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See if there's air in the gas line system. But let's check if the heater lights. Ellen laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's funny?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I didn't know it was actually broken. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don't you come over here? For a moment, they just stare at each other. She smiles. There is a palpable sexual tension between them. Ben walks away from her, over to the water heater.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You're a very attractive woman. Ellen moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In another life, I'd like nothing more than to make love to you with the passion and staying power of a sex-obsessed 17-year old boy.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That sounds nice.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: But I just lost my wife. Her demeanor changes, transforming instantly from flirtat to maternal.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, I am so sorry. When?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Five days ago. The recent nature of this makes Ellen gasp. She slowly mo to Ben and hugs him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. I'm fine. He gently pushes her off of him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Your wife just died.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Honey. She reaches for him again.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Ben moves away from her and lights the water heater. EXT. RV_“CAMPGROUND” - POOL. NIGHT. Claire sits next to a swimming pool, her feet in the wate bobbing her head to the music coming out of her iPod.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: What's your favorite music? Bo considers this.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Probably Bach. Especially the Goldberg Variations. Mainly Glenn Gould's version. But I also like the Unaccompanied Cello Suites, preferably when played by Yo-Yo Ma. This makes Karen smile.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: All over. Most recently Paris. In the Marais. Near Victor Hugo's house. My family's only here for my dad's sabbatical. He's working on a book about... Dr. Spock.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Star Trek's awesome. 63. 69 70 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Which star?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Spock. The guy with the ears. He's from Star Trek.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: No, he was from Connecticut, I'm pretty sure. Right after Yale, he wrote "Baby and Child Care" in 1946. One of the seminal works on child- rearing. Claire laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I was talking about that old TV show.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Right. I know that one. It's... awesome. Where's your dad?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: He got remarried and moved to Florida. He’s a fucking dickhead. We don’t talk about him. Where's your Mom?

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to talk about it. She works for the U.S. government.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Like James Bond? Again, Bo doesn't know this reference.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: I don't... know. I'm not supposed to talk about it. Due to its highly classified nature.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Seriously? My Mom works for an insurance company. Claire smiles at Bo, clearly taken with him. He tries to hold her gaze, but can't.  71 GREEN (9.2.2014) 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire and Bo walk through the mostly dark RV park. She g his hand and pulls him toward her. Her body is so close t Bo can smell her. She kisses him. Bo is utterly stunned. This is his first kiss. He's slow respond, but then, he can't stop. It's tender and sweet. Bo's face is flushed and he's breathing rapidly. Instantl and deeply in love. He looks like he might cry.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You okay? Bo nods and she kisses him again. This time, the kiss las much longer.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You kiss good.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: So do you. They kiss again, this time their hands exploring each oth bodies. Claire finally breaks it off.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Follow me. But we have to be totally quiet. He nods and they sneak behind a few trailers.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's almost midnight. Bo and Claire turn to see Ellen, Claire's Mom, waiting up a chair in front of her Winnebago. She smokes a cigarette looks very pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I sincerely hope you two lovebirds haven't been doing what I think you've been doing. Bo look at Claire. Then he gets down on one knee. He clea his throat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: I'm considering a career in computer programming. Which can be highly lucrative. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though, of course, I'm young, so I'll keep my options open. I don't have my own house. Obviously. But I know I could provide a good home. Someday I want kids. Not now. Of course. Someday. I'm not religious, but I'm tolerant. If you are. Religious that is, not tolerant. Or... both. What's your last name?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: McCune.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Claire McCune. Will you be my wife? Claire stares at Bo. Then she looks at her Mom. Then they both burst out laughing. For a moment, Bo isn't sure what to do. His face turns re He stands. And tries to pretend like he was joking.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Okay, funnyman. Your dad's probably waiting up. Bo nods.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: "Night. Bo nods again and stumbles toward Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bo has made breakfast for the other kids. They're all outside, sitting on benches, eating oatmeal. The door to Steve flies open, slamming hard against the s Ben strides out, naked. He stretches. AN ELDERLY COUPLE walks by. They gawk at Ben, a completel naked man.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It's just a penis. Every man has one. The kids stare at Ben, eating their cereal, not the sligh bit embarrassed. Like he's done this a thousand times bef (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Which he has. As Ben continues, a few of the kids mouth t words along with him.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are not Puritans. We are all just animals of the earth. Is a dog embarrassed to defecate in the dirt? Of course not. Appalled, the couple scurries away.

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: You get to put your penis away now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen and Claire wave goodbye. Bo is in the back seat, looking out the window, staring a Claire as the bus drives away. Face so close, his breath the glass. He places his hand on the window. A silent goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve drives along a Highway 40, a vast desert on all sid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben grabs the PA radio.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, if I can have your attention please. About four hours south of here lies Camp Grant. In the late 1800s, whites arrived in this area by the thousands, depleting the food and water supplies of the indigenous people. Horrific acts of violence were committed on both sides. But as the US government wasn't doing anything about the frisky natives, people thought they'd better settle this themselves. So in the pre-dawn hours of April 30, 1871, 146 armed men surprised a camp of Apaches. Almost all women and children, as the men were off hunting for food. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eight old men and 110 women and children were massacred in under 30 minutes. Twenty-seven children were sold into slavery in Mexico. This was the Camp Grant massacre. No one was ever prosecuted. Today, there is no physical marker locating this site, no day of remembrance. He lets this settle in.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On a lighter note, we should be at Nana and Grandpa's in about four and half hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the bus exits the freeway. The terrain here is marked different. Long gone are the mountains of evergreens. It' now the red dirt and rock formations of the Southwest des

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by cactus and palm trees, hundreds of rotor sprinklers SHOOT water over a vast golf course. Steve winds past the course, which stretches into the distance, as far as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus drives by the iron gate of a gated community, the sign on the gate reads, "Coronado Ridge." Ben drives by without pausing.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Wait! Why aren’t we stopping at Nana and Grandpa's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve pulls into the parking lot of St. Jude’s church and parks at the far end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's now morning and Ben is wearing a baby blue vintage tuxedo, the shirt with enormous ruffles. He's helping the kids, as they scramble around, trying to get dressed. Each kid is wearing their favorite piece of clothing. The twins wear pink tights and Tu-Tus, Nai has on his frayed Whale costume, Zaja is wearing what looks like some kind military outfit, and Bo is wearing his thrift-store suit. Rellian is still in his pajamas, staring at them all.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: We can't go like this.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We can do whatever we want.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: Then I'm not getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Then go in your pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: Dad, please?! Please. Everyone is going to laugh at us.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Who cares what total strangers think? This is for Mom. She'd love what you're wearing. She'd think it was fun.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: We're supposed to wear black! It's a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: For them it's a funeral. For us - this is her goodbye party. And we're not wearing black to a party!  82 83 84 85 86 GREEN (9.2.2014) 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the front doors of the church, Jack and Abigail, visibly distraught, holding hands, stagger from a black limousine and make their way into the church. Harper, Dave, Justin and Jackson get out of the limousine behind them and trail them into the church.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 85
dialogues.text: INT. ST. JUDE’S CHURCH. DAY. 86 A sea of mourners in BLACK sit a large Catholic church fo the funeral Mass. The PRIEST stands in front of the congregation, an enormo statue of Christ on the Cross above the altar at his back he speaks, in a warm and caring voice, incense smoke rise behind him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: O God, to whom mercy and forgiveness belong, hear our prayers on behalf of your servant Leslie Cash, whom you have called out of the world: and because she put her hope and trust in you, command that she be carried safely home to Heaven and come to enjoy your eternal reward. Amen. The entire crowd repeats, "Amen." Just then, Ben and his brightly-colored family walk to th front of the church. They pass Harper, Dave, Justin and Jackson, who find it h to mask their utter shock at the sight of what Ben and hi kids are wearing. Ben and the kids sit in the first row. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack and Abigail, also in the first row, now turn to see and his family. Jack's face turns bright red, but there i nothing he can do now. Ben nods at Jack. Jack looks away, at the priest. The priest eyes the newcomers for a second, then continue

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I did not know Leslie personally. And I am poorer for it. But I understand that she was a loving mother who gave up her law practice to raise her children. Leslie loved her mother, Angela, her father, Jack, and their dogs, Harvey and Little Bear. They have told me that she also loved gardening. And classical music. Particularly Glenn Gould's version of the Goldberg Variations. And walks in the moonlight on the beach. And she loved her husband Ben and their children -

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'll take that as my cue, if I may. Before Jack can stop him, Ben jogs to the front of the church. He stands directly in front of the priest.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First off, Leslie practiced Buddhism. Which, to her, was a philosophy and not an organized religion. In fact, Leslie abhorred organized religion, thought it the single most dangerous fairy-tale ever invented, used to strike fear and obedience into the hearts of the innocent and uninformed. She saw it not just as a source of injustice, but as a crime against humanity. To her - the only thing worse than death would have been the knowledge that her rotting flesh was to be trapped for all eternity in a box in the middle of a fucking golf course. At this, there are audible GASPS from the congregation. Jack pushes his way out of the pew and whispers to some USHERS IN BLACK SUITS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though the absurdity of being eulogized by someone who didn't even know her has exactly the kind of comedic flourish that she would have cherished. Ben looks at his kids. They nod at him, encouraging him t continue.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If nothing else. Leslie had a sense of humor. Ushers in black suits, guided by Jack, now inch toward th podium.

dialogues.speaker: USHER
dialogues.text: Sir? Please? Ben ignores them. He takes a piece of paper from his jack

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I want to read you all something. So you know what I mean. I found this after her death. It's Leslie's Will. And I quote, "In the event of her death, Leslie Abigail Cash, as a Buddhist, wishes to be cremated. Her funeral, such as it is, shall be a celebration of the life-cycle, with music and dancing. After, it is her expressed desire that her ashes shall be taken to a nondescript location, preferably public and heavily populated so as to be utterly unremarkable. At which point her ashes, promptly and unceremoniously, are to be flushed down the nearest toilet." End quote. Ben looks up at the mourners.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now THAT's comedy. The ushers rush Ben. He resists, but there are too many m for Ben to fight and he is overpowered.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not finished! You're not listening. She did not want this! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The ushers drag Ben toward the entrance of the church.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let go of me! This is against her wishes! She was my wife! Bo gathers the kids and they follow as their father is dragged - fighting - out of the church. EXT. ST. JUDE’S CHURCH. DAY. 87 Ben sits on a bench next to the front doors of the church The children, despondent and dazed, sit farther off, on a grassy knoll. The church doors open and PALLBEARERS, followed by Jack a Abigail; Harper, Dave and their kids, and various other RELATIVES, accompany the casket to the waiting Hearse. The CONGREGATION moves to their cars, giving the family t privacy. Jack looks up to find Ben, not three feet away.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You are the worst thing that has ever happened to my family. The kids straggle up.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jack, you remember your grandchildren. Only now does Jack see the kids. In an instant, he soften bending down to embrace his grandchildren.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Come here, guys. I’ve missed you all so much. Come here. He and Abigail wade into the kids. Abigail looks dazed. O severely medicated.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: It's so nice to all be together.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We’ll take the children to the ceremony. And see you back at the house after. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They're my kids. They’re staying with me. Jack stares at Ben for a moment. Then he addresses his grandchildren.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Children. I’m sorry it’s turned out this way. But your father has demonstrated that he is unfit to attend the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I won’t allow you to bury her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You follow us. I will have you arrested. Ben laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who do you think the local police are going to listen to? A long- standing member of this community? Or a hippie. Dressed like a clown. Jack faces Ben for a moment. Then he takes Abigail by the and they move to their limousine.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'm not a hippie. The kids watch as their grandparent's limousine disappear into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone back on Steve! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We're going to stop the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: He said no. Dad! But Ben's already on the bus, the engine running.  88 89 90 GREEN (9.2.2014) 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long line of black cars funnel into the rolling hills a cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is keeping a fair distance, but still following the funeral procession of black cars.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: We can't go. Dad!

dialogues.speaker: VESPYR
dialogues.text: Listen to us!

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: Why can't we go to Mom's funeral?

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Because of dad.

dialogues.speaker: NAI
dialogues.text: Because of his speech?

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Everyone shut up! And sit the fuck down! I want silence. SILENCE!

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR BODEVAN
dialogues.text: No! Dad, stop Steve! Dad! You heard grandpa! He'll have us arrested if we show up.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They will not stop us from saving Mom!

dialogues.speaker: KIELYR VESPYR
dialogues.text: Let's go home. Let's just go Dad! Abort the mission! home!

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: Yeah, abort mission! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We are rescuing Mom!

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Mom is dead! She's dead! Okay?! This is not what she would have wanted you to do!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They have no right! Bo now yells.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: I don't want to lose you! This stops Ben. He looks at Bo.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can't lose you too. Ben finally hears his son. And it breaks his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben sits outside the bus, playing his guitar in front of small fire. Zaja tries to sneak on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hey, get your flute. Let's play. Zaja stares at him; she seems to be hiding something behi her back.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What have you got there? She opens her hands revealing a dead lizard.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: I have work to do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GREEN, (9.2.2014)
dialogues.text: 92 Zaja climbs on the bus. EXT. RESIDENTIAL STREET NEAR “CAMPGROUND.” NIGHT. 93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet street, lit by a long line of street lamps. Rell throwing rocks at one of them. Bo walks out of the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: It's okay to be sad about Mom. Rell just keeps flinging rocks at the light. Bo laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: She wanted to be flushed down the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Mom was sicker than any of us knew.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN
dialogues.text: Dad MADE her crazy. That's why she killed herself. She wanted to leave. She didn’t want to live in the forest anymore. Dad is dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom had psychotic episodes. She had hallucinations. Of smashing our heads in. With rocks. I heard them talking about it. Bo stares at his brother, absorbing this new information.

dialogues.speaker: RELLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think you know everything. You think our lives are so great. You think Dad is perfect! Nana and Grandpa's lives. They're much better. Rell turns and races back toward the RV Camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben walks out of the bus and finds Bo, reading.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You want to play some music? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bo opens his backpack and hands Ben his stack of college acceptance letters. Ben sits in front of the fire. He rea the letters. After he finishes, there's a long moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well done.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Very impressive.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: I guess. Ben passes the letters back to Bo.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: All this time, you've been deceiving me.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I allowed you to go to the library and you were sneaking around behind my back, taking the SATs, contacting and applying to universities.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: Not like that.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We're not an accredited home-school, but secretly, you filled out these applications, you got your work approved, you managed to create acceptable transcripts.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: All without my knowledge or approval. I don't know what's more impressive. The fact that you got into all these schools. Or that for months, you were lying directly to my face! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: It was Mom. Ben is silent. This is clearly a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She helped me. With everything. We did it together. I just want to go to college.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You speak four languages. High math! Theoretical physics! What are they going to teach you there?

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: I know nothing. Ben stares at his son.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom understood! She knew! We're freaks. You've made us freaks. Unless it came out of a book. I don't know anything about ANYTHING! Bo storms into the bus. Ben sits there for a second, at a loss. xe NAI (0.S8.) Dad? Ben looks up to see Nai, naked.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Put on some clothes, buddy. Nai shakes his head no. He holds a piece of paper and rea

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: "Don't try and get me. This is real this time. - Rellian."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the kids are standing, peering out the windows as the drive Steve down a city street.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He couldn't have got very far. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAIL
dialogues.text: Is he going to die?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: According to recent FBI statistics, in exurban and suburban semi-dense residential areas, there was an average of 1,242 incidences of violent crime, murder, forcible rape, aggravated assault -

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Zaj!

dialogues.speaker: ZAJA
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, he COULD die. Statistically speaking.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He'll be fine. Rell is confused. We're all confused. The world is a confusing place. We just have to find him.

dialogues.speaker: BODEVAN
dialogues.text: I know where he went. Everyone turns to look at Bo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben jumps off the bus and runs up to the front door of Ja and Abigail's house, followed by Bo, Vespyr, and Kielyr.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Bo, make sure everyone stays on Steve! Bo pushes the twins back toward Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben pushes his way into the house, Abigail right behind h

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: Ben, no. No! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Abigail steps in front of him, physically stopping him. Behind them, all over the walls, are mounted game trophie deer, wild boar, pheasants.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Where is he? Abigail pauses, seeing the anxiety on Ben's face.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's my son. Abigail finally nods her head.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: Follow me. And she leads him down a hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben follows Abigail into the dark, game simulator room. O one entire wall is a large projected image: a field, blue sky, trees in the background.
